key: _claude-sonnet-4__In trawl fisheries, what are the most effective gear modifications for reducing unwanted fish catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The most effective gear modifications for reducing unwanted fish catch in trawl fisheries include several categories of modifications.
[Statement 2]: Size-sorting escape grids fitted to trawl nets showed effectiveness in reducing unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 3]: Various grid types reduced catches of unwanted small mackerel, small monkfish, non-target whiting and haddock, small hake, unwanted spiny dogfish, non-target herring, prohibited halibut, and unwanted sizes of cod compared to trawls without grids.
[Statement 4]: Combined mesh escape panels with size-sorting grids showed strong results in reducing unwanted catch of fish, sharks and stingrays compared to standard unmodified trawl nets.
[Statement 5]: Size-sorting escape grids with large escape openings were effective in reducing catches of unwanted fish, sharks and rays compared to standard trawl nets.
[Statement 6]: Square mesh codends demonstrated effectiveness in reducing unwanted catches of all monitored fish species, young individuals of commercially targeted fish, total unwanted catch, and discarded fish compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 7]: Mesh escape panels or windows showed positive results in reducing unwanted catches of various fish species compared to standard diamond mesh trawl nets.
[Statement 8]: Size-sorting mesh funnels in shrimp trawls were effective in reducing catches of unwanted non-commercial or discarded fish compared to standard trawls.
[Statement 9]: Topless (coverless) trawls showed effectiveness in reducing the catch of unwanted Atlantic cod and discards of commercial fish species compared to conventional trawl types.
[Statement 10]: Bottom trawls with parts raised off the seabed were effective in catching fewer unwanted sharks, elasmobranchs and fish compared to conventional trawls.
[Statement 11]: Removing tickler chains showed effectiveness in reducing catches of non-commercial target skates, rays and sharks.
[Statement 12]: Removing tickler chains typically did not affect catches of commercial target species.
[Statement 13]: Artificial lights on fishing gear showed limited effectiveness in reducing unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 14]: Shrimp trawl nets with lights caught fewer unwanted fish when the lights were fitted to the fishing line compared to a conventional trawl.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence for management interventions successfully reducing fishing effort?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on the examined studies, evidence for management interventions successfully reducing fishing effort is limited and mixed.
[Statement 2]: One study in the Pacific Ocean found that co-management systems showed no decrease in overall fishing effort in the managed area five years after implementation.
[Statement 3]: Territorial fishing use rights showed no decrease in overall fishing effort in the five years after implementation in the Pacific Ocean.
[Statement 4]: Move-on rules that establish temporary fishing restrictions when catch thresholds are reached showed promising results.
[Statement 5]: Two studies in the North Atlantic Ocean and North Sea found that fishing effort for cod and blue ling was reduced after the implementation of move-on rules.
[Statement 6]: Overall catch limits showed variable effects on fishing effort.
[Statement 7]: One study in the North Sea found that when annual total allowable catch limits were changed, half of the otter trawl fleet had corresponding changes in fishing effort.
[Statement 8]: The same study found no changes in fishing effort for the beam trawl fleet when annual total allowable catch limits were changed.
[Statement 9]: Many management interventions lacked direct studies evaluating the effects of those interventions on fishing effort reduction.
[Statement 10]: Vessel decommissioning schemes lacked direct studies evaluating their effects on fishing effort reduction.
[Statement 11]: Fishing permit limitations lacked direct studies evaluating their effects on fishing effort reduction.
[Statement 12]: Gear and vessel restrictions lacked direct studies evaluating their effects on fishing effort reduction.

[Statement 1]: Several actions are available to protect the reproductive success of commercially fished species.
[Statement 2]: Protecting spawning fish from capture can safeguard reproduction directly.
[Statement 3]: Studies have shown that spawning and nursery areas closed seasonally or permanently to fishing were used by tagged adult Atlantic cod for nearly a third of the time during spawning.
[Statement 4]: Setting a minimum landing size for commercially fished species can protect immature fish before the fish have the opportunity to reproduce.
[Statement 5]: A global review found that only one of five swordfish fisheries showed increased recruitment after setting recommended minimum landing sizes.
[Statement 6]: One study reported that most fish in commercial catches were still immature despite established minimum sizes.
[Statement 7]: Temporal restrictions include establishing temporary fishery closures.
[Statement 8]: Tagged adult cod spent nearly a third of their time inside a seasonally closed spawning area, which provided increased protection during the spawning period.
[Statement 9]: Long-term fishery closures can protect fish populations.
[Statement 10]: Studies showed a higher abundance of young salmon and improved weights of young salmon returning to rivers in the five years after the closure of a commercial coastal fishery.
[Statement 11]: Establishing territorial user rights for fisheries demonstrated benefits for reproductive success.
[Statement 12]: One study found larger-sized and more numerous egg capsules, and more larvae of Chilean abalone up to 21 months after establishing fishing restrictions compared to open-access areas.
[Statement 13]: Gear modifications can reduce the capture of juvenile fish before the fish reach reproductive maturity.
[Statement 14]: Using larger mesh sizes in fishing nets improved size-selectivity and reduced catches of unwanted small or undersized fish in 15 of 20 studies across multiple marine regions.
[Statement 15]: Using larger mesh sizes in fishing nets allows juvenile fish to escape and reach reproductive age.
[Statement 16]: Marine Protected Areas that prohibit commercial fishing can protect both spawning grounds and nursery areas.
[Statement 17]: The effectiveness of Marine Protected Areas varies by species and implementation.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What actions are available to protect the reproductive success of commercially fished species?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Prohibiting spearfishing in marine reserves in the Mediterranean provides several conservation benefits for fish populations.
[Statement 2]: Prohibiting spearfishing and line fishing in protected areas in the Mediterranean Sea increased the abundances of European seabass and gilthead seabream compared to fished areas after two to seven years.
[Statement 3]: European seabass were larger in size in Mediterranean areas where spearfishing was prohibited compared to fished areas after two to seven years.
[Statement 4]: Prohibiting spearfishing in specific zones of a Mediterranean marine reserve resulted in higher commercial and recreational fishery catches of targeted common dentex compared to zones that allowed spearfishing after one to three years.
[Statement 5]: Marine protected areas in the Mediterranean Sea prohibiting all types of fishing for between three and 16 years had different fish community composition compared to fished areas.
[Statement 6]: Mediterranean marine protected areas that had prohibited all fishing for between one to more than 25 years had higher fish species richness compared to fished areas.
[Statement 7]: Mediterranean marine protected areas that prohibited all fishing for up to 25 years had higher abundances and biomasses of all fish compared to unprotected fished areas.
[Statement 8]: Fishery targeted fish species had higher abundances and biomasses in Mediterranean marine protected areas that prohibited all fishing for up to 25 years compared to unprotected fished areas.
[Statement 9]: Fish in non-fished Mediterranean marine reserves were found to be larger overall compared to fished areas after one to 22 years.
[Statement 10]: Non-fished Mediterranean marine reserves had larger individuals of monitored fish species compared to fished areas after one to 22 years.
[Statement 11]: More eggs of four commercially targeted fish species were found inside a non-fished Mediterranean marine reserve enforced for three years than in fished areas outside the reserve.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the conservation benefits of prohibiting spearfishing in marine reserves in the Mediterranean?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Studies examining the prohibition of different types of bottom fishing gear show varied effects on marine fish populations.
[Statement 2]: Prohibiting all mobile and static fishing gears that catch bottom species showed mixed results.
[Statement 3]: One study found that prohibiting all mobile and static fishing gears led to higher numbers of larger and older cod after 15 years.
[Statement 4]: Another study found no effect on fish densities after 2-7 years of prohibiting all mobile and static fishing gears.
[Statement 5]: Cod showed better growth in areas closed to fishing for 5-15 years compared to openly fished areas.
[Statement 6]: Prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor, also known as bottom trawling, had variable effects on fish abundance across studies.
[Statement 7]: Two studies found that prohibiting bottom trawling resulted in increased total fish biomass after 15 years.
[Statement 8]: Some studies found a higher biomass of adult red mullet after 14 years of prohibiting bottom trawling.
[Statement 9]: Two other studies found no effect on bottom-dwelling fish abundance after 5 and 10 years of prohibiting bottom trawling.
[Statement 10]: Red mullet recruitment increased after 14 years of closing an area to bottom trawling.
[Statement 11]: Haddock recruitment showed no improvement after an area was closed to bottom trawling for 7 years.
[Statement 12]: Fish size responses to prohibiting bottom trawling varied.
[Statement 13]: Adult red mullet were larger 14 years after an area was closed to bottom trawling.
[Statement 14]: The overall effects of prohibiting bottom trawling on fish size were mixed across studies and varied by fish group and habitat type.
[Statement 15]: Prohibiting shellfish dredging specifically showed no effect on bottom-dwelling fish species richness or abundance after 10 years in one North Sea study.
[Statement 16]: The use of semi-pelagic trawl instead of bottom trawl reduced commercial fish catch abundance compared to demersal trawling.
[Statement 17]: Areas allowing only hook and line fishing showed greater increases in lobster abundance over 4 years compared to fully fished sites.
[Statement 18]: Areas allowing only hook and line fishing showed greater increases in lobster size over 4 years compared to fully fished sites.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the effects on marine fish populations of prohibiting different types of bottom fishing gear?
_claude-sonnet-4__What are some alternatives to setting catch quotas for controlling fishing mortality?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several alternatives to setting catch quotas exist for controlling fishing mortality.
[Statement 2]: Effort controls include limiting the number of fishing days.
[Statement 3]: Limiting the number of fishing days resulted in higher biomass of thornback and brown rays in the Mediterranean Sea following a decrease in the overall number of days fished by a bottom trawl fleet.
[Statement 4]: Vessel restrictions can limit fishing activity by vessel size and/or engine power.
[Statement 5]: In the North Sea, excluding vessels with higher engine power from an area for half of each year resulted in a higher abundance of commercially targeted fish.
[Statement 6]: Licensing systems can limit the number of fishing permits or licences to limit vessel or fisher numbers.
[Statement 7]: No studies were found evaluating the use of licensing systems to limit vessel or fisher numbers.
[Statement 8]: Technical measures for controlling fishing mortality include prohibiting certain gear types.
[Statement 9]: Prohibiting certain gear types showed higher fish density in areas where all but one gear type was prohibited compared to areas with fewer restrictions or unrestricted areas.
[Statement 10]: Using larger mesh sizes can reduce unwanted catch and improve size-selectivity.
[Statement 11]: Studies showed that using larger mesh sizes reduced catches of unwanted fish in most cases.
[Statement 12]: Using larger mesh sizes improved size-selectivity for all fish species assessed.
[Statement 13]: Limiting or prohibiting specific fishing methods has been implemented as a control on fishing mortality.
[Statement 14]: Limited evidence exists on the effectiveness of limiting or prohibiting specific fishing methods.
[Statement 15]: Spatial and temporal restrictions include establishing temporary fishery closures and long-term fishery closures.
[Statement 16]: Long-term fishery closures showed varied results, including higher abundance of some fish species in closed areas.
[Statement 17]: Long-term fishery closures also showed a reduced flight response distance in fish in closed areas.
[Statement 18]: Move-on rules, which establish temporary fishing restrictions when catch thresholds are reached, have reduced cod discards and fishing effort.
[Statement 19]: Rights-based management alternatives include catch shares systems.
[Statement 20]: Fisheries managed under catch shares were more likely to meet biomass sustainability targets compared to non-catch share fisheries.
[Statement 21]: Fisheries managed under catch shares had lower rates of over-exploitation compared to non-catch share fisheries.
[Statement 22]: Setting catch shares by species reduced unwanted halibut catch in a multi-species fishery compared to previous systems.

[Statement 1]: Different fishing practices significantly affect fish survival after capture and release.
[Statement 2]: Hook and line fishing provides greater fish vitality, which is an indicator of post-release survival, compared to other gear types.
[Statement 3]: Fish survival rates vary considerably by species and capture conditions.
[Statement 4]: Studies have shown that 76-92% of unwanted small-spotted catshark, thorny skate, pearl perch, and Atlantic wolffish survived for 1 hour to 5 days after capture and release.
[Statement 5]: Less than half of smooth skate survived after capture and release.
[Statement 6]: Nearly all yelloweye rockfish survived for four days after capture and release.
[Statement 7]: Canary rockfish survival decreased with increasing capture depth.
[Statement 8]: The type of hook used for fishing affects survival outcomes.
[Statement 9]: Using different hook types in longline or recreational fisheries reduced fish hook injuries that are associated with higher post-release mortality.
[Statement 10]: The use of different hook types reduced capture mortality of some unwanted shark and ray species compared to conventional hooks.
[Statement 11]: Other studies found no reduction in post-release mortality for certain species like young sea breams when using different hook types.
[Statement 12]: Circle hooks specifically show mixed effects on survival.
[Statement 13]: Two studies found similar survival rates for sea turtles caught by circle hooks versus J-hooks.
[Statement 14]: One review found fewer sea turtle deaths when circle hooks were used in four of five fisheries.
[Statement 15]: Fish survival is negatively affected by injuries from hooking and capture depth.
[Statement 16]: Longer tow durations negatively affect fish survival.
[Statement 17]: Modifications to longline configurations also impact survival.
[Statement 18]: For two of three species studied, nylon hook attachment lines showed higher survival for unwanted sharks and rays compared to wire.
[Statement 19]: One study found reduced survival for a species when using nylon hook lines.
[Statement 20]: According to one global systematic review, using different bait types did not increase the survival of sharks and rays on gear retrieval.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What does the evidence say about how different fishing practices affect the survival of fish after capture and release?
_claude-sonnet-4__How do the effects of prohibiting all commercial fishing on fish abundance vary across different ocean basins?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The effects of prohibiting all commercial fishing on fish abundance show considerable variation across different ocean basins.
[Statement 2]: In the Tasman Sea, studies found mixed results, with most fish species in an estuary showing lower abundance two years after a commercial fishing closure.
[Statement 3]: A separate study in the Tasman Sea found that fish abundance varied over 10 years and was higher for some groups compared to areas open to fishing.
[Statement 4]: In the Indian Ocean, areas banning all commercial fishing for five years showed higher abundances of three of twelve commercially targeted and non-targeted fish species compared to unprotected fished areas.
[Statement 5]: In the Indian Ocean, the overall size of fish was bigger in areas that banned all commercial fishing for five years.
[Statement 6]: In the Mediterranean Sea, studies showed no increase in white seabream and gilthead bream biomass 2-13 years after a fishing closure compared to unprotected fished areas.
[Statement 7]: In the South Atlantic Ocean, a reserve closed to all commercial fishing for 40 years showed higher abundances of five of five commercially exploited species.
[Statement 8]: The same reserve in the South Atlantic Ocean that was closed for 40 years showed no change in species composition compared to fished areas.
[Statement 9]: The Gulf of Mexico showed higher abundances of one of four commercially targeted fish species in protected areas.
[Statement 10]: In the South China Sea, the overall fish density in the wider region increased in the five years after the creation of marine reserves with commercial fishing limits.
[Statement 11]: More comprehensive studies across multiple ocean basins found that marine protected areas prohibiting all fishing for up to 25 years or more generally had higher fish abundances.
[Statement 12]: The effects of fishing prohibitions on fish abundance varied between fish species, food chain position, commercial target status, fish sizes, depth, and habitat types.
[Statement 13]: Studies spanning numerous ocean basins found that 30 of 54 studies showed higher fish abundances in protected areas.
[Statement 14]: Out of 54 studies spanning numerous ocean basins, 8 showed similar fish abundances in protected and unprotected areas.
[Statement 15]: Out of 54 studies spanning numerous ocean basins, 16 showed mixed effects on fish abundance depending on species characteristics.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the most effective non-gear-modification strategies for reducing unwanted fish catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several non-gear-modification strategies have been evaluated for reducing unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 2]: Establishing move-on rules for temporary, targeted fishing restrictions or closures when a catch threshold is reached has shown effectiveness.
[Statement 3]: One study found lower overall cod discards after the implementation of move-on rules.
[Statement 4]: Setting catch limits or quotas for non-targeted commercial catch was found to reduce unwanted catch in two of three cases according to a review.
[Statement 5]: One study found that catch limits for non-target commercial species reduced the amount of unwanted halibut.
[Statement 6]: Temporary fishery closures demonstrated benefits for turtle populations.
[Statement 7]: One study found fewer lethal strandings of loggerhead and Kemp's ridley turtles during seasonal shrimp trawling closures.
[Statement 8]: Technology to communicate near real-time catch information to fishers showed promise, with reductions of unwanted catch or discards reported in two of three cases.
[Statement 9]: Prohibiting high grading, which is landing only the most profitable individuals or species, did not eliminate the discarding of legal-sized but unwanted fish in one study.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of human observers onboard fishing vessels on reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of vessel monitoring systems on reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 12]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of promoting seafood certification on reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 13]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of legislating mandatory landing of all quota species catch on reducing unwanted catch.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What management actions are available to specifically protect the reproductive capacity of fish populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several management actions are available to specifically protect the reproductive capacity of fish populations.
[Statement 2]: Protecting spawning fish from capture is a direct management approach.
[Statement 3]: Protecting spawning fish involves seasonal fishery closures to protect spawning individuals.
[Statement 4]: Studies have shown that spawning areas closed seasonally or permanently to fishing were used by tagged adult Atlantic cod for nearly a third of the time during spawning.
[Statement 5]: Releasing males of species known to guard nests during the breeding season is a targeted approach.
[Statement 6]: No studies have yet evaluated the effects on marine fish populations of releasing males of species known to guard nests.
[Statement 7]: Establishing temporary fishery closures provides broader protection for fish populations.
[Statement 8]: Studies have shown that tagged adult cod spent nearly a third of their time inside seasonally closed spawning areas during the closures' implementation.
[Statement 9]: Temporarily closed spawning areas provide increased protection from fishing gears during the spawning period.
[Statement 10]: Setting minimum landing sizes for commercially fished species helps protect immature fish before the fish reach reproductive maturity.
[Statement 11]: One study reported that despite established minimum sizes, most fish landed in commercial catches were immature and had never spawned.
[Statement 12]: Allowing periodic fishing only is an additional management approach.
[Statement 13]: One study found that protected areas fished only for short periods had greater biomass than openly fished areas.
[Statement 14]: One study found that protected areas fished only for short periods had similar fish biomass as areas permanently closed to fishing.
[Statement 15]: Size range specifications are an available management tool.
[Statement 16]: Maximum landing size limits are an available management tool.
[Statement 17]: No studies have yet evaluated the specific effects of size range specifications and maximum landing size limits on fish reproductive capacity.

[Statement 1]: The evidence for the effectiveness of involving fishers and other stakeholders in marine conservation management is extremely limited.
[Statement 2]: Only three studies have examined the effect of involving fishers and stakeholders in co-management on marine fish populations.
[Statement 3]: These three studies were conducted in the Indian Ocean, the South China Sea in Vietnam, and the Pacific Ocean in Tonga.
[Statement 4]: One study found increased overall fish abundance nine years after the implementation of co-management.
[Statement 5]: Another study found no increase in total fish catch rates and decreased catch rates in half of the six species groups after five years of co-management.
[Statement 6]: One study reported decreased illegal fishing using destructive fishing gears after co-management was established.
[Statement 7]: Another study found no decrease in overall fishing effort after five years of implementing co-management.
[Statement 8]: For most other stakeholder involvement approaches, no studies were found that evaluated their effects.
[Statement 9]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of engaging stakeholders or fishers in scientific research and data collection.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of including fishers in management groups for marine protected areas.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of engaging with stakeholders when designing Marine Protected Areas.
[Statement 12]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of promoting knowledge exchange between fishers.
[Statement 13]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of involving stakeholders in the allocation of harvest rights.
[Statement 14]: Community-based fisheries management resulted in higher New Zealand scallop abundance but smaller scallop size compared to other management types.
[Statement 15]: Territorial user rights for fisheries led to larger-sized and more numerous egg capsules and more larvae of Chilean abalone compared to open-access areas.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the state of evidence for the effectiveness of involving fishers and other stakeholders in marine conservation management?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Deploying fishing gear at selected depths can avoid unwanted species.
[Statement 2]: Deploying fishing gear above the seabed, instead of on the seabed, reduced unwanted catches of various fish species and sharks compared to depths usually fished.
[Statement 3]: Deploying fishing gear at selected times, such as during the day or night, can avoid unwanted species.
[Statement 4]: Trawling for prawns during the day reduced the overall catch of unwanted fish by number compared to usual night trawling.
[Statement 5]: The effect of daytime prawn trawling on reducing unwanted fish catch differed by species.
[Statement 6]: Powered handlining in the day avoided catches of Harrison's dogfish at shallower seamounts compared to night fishing.
[Statement 7]: The use of technology to provide near real-time catch information to fishers has resulted in reductions of unwanted catch or discards in some cases.
[Statement 8]: Establishing proper handling and release protocols can help manage unwanted catch.
[Statement 9]: Enhanced release protocols with minimal handling and air exposure allowed reef fish to return more quickly to a reef or seabed after release compared to higher stress handling.
[Statement 10]: Whale sharks released using enhanced protocols showed normal post-release movements.
[Statement 11]: Releasing protected or species of concern alive after capture is a tactic to reduce the impact of bycatch.
[Statement 12]: The majority of various unwanted fish species survived for at least 1 hour to 5 days after capture and release.
[Statement 13]: The survival of released unwanted fish species was affected by capture depth and tow duration.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the most effective operational tactics for fishers to reduce unwanted catch without modifying the main structure of their nets or lines?
_claude-sonnet-4__Besides closing areas to fishing, what alternative management strategies can reduce overall fishing mortality?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several alternative management strategies can reduce overall fishing mortality besides closing areas to fishing.
[Statement 2]: Overall catch limits or quotas by fishery or fleet can decrease fishing mortality.
[Statement 3]: Overall catch limits or quotas by fishery or fleet can improve fish survival.
[Statement 4]: Studies showed faster biomass increases for overfished tuna and billfish stocks when those stocks were managed using catch limits compared to other controls.
[Statement 5]: Setting catch limits or quotas for non-targeted commercial catch reduced unwanted catch in two of three cases.
[Statement 6]: Setting catch limits or quotas for non-targeted commercial catch reduced the amount of unwanted halibut.
[Statement 7]: Stocks in commercial fisheries with long-term management plans were more likely to be sustainable compared to fisheries without long-term objectives.
[Statement 8]: Stocks in commercial fisheries with long-term management plans were less likely to be in decline compared to fisheries without long-term objectives.
[Statement 9]: Gear modifications can reduce fishing mortality by minimizing unwanted catch.
[Statement 10]: Fitting size-sorting mesh funnels (sieve nets) to prawn and shrimp trawl nets reduced catches of unwanted fish compared to standard trawls.
[Statement 11]: Modifying bottom trawls to raise parts of the gear off the seabed caught fewer unwanted sharks and other fish.
[Statement 12]: Fitting size-sorting escape grids and large escape openings to trawl nets reduced catches of unwanted fish and sharks in three of four studies.
[Statement 13]: Limiting fishing activity by vessel size and/or engine power showed a higher abundance of commercially targeted fish.
[Statement 14]: A higher abundance of commercially targeted fish was found after excluding vessels with higher engine power from an area for half of each year.

[Statement 1]: Several actions are available within marine protected areas to manage fishing activity without imposing complete bans.
[Statement 2]: Restricting unspecified fishing activity in marine protected areas can result in higher fish abundance, survival, and larger average sizes compared to unprotected areas.
[Statement 3]: Controlling human activity with a zonation system of restrictions allows for different levels of fishing restrictions across zones.
[Statement 4]: Studies have found higher fish species richness, abundance, and larger sizes in zones where fishing is more restricted compared to zones with fewer restrictions.
[Statement 5]: Marine protected areas can introduce some unspecified fishing restrictions while still allowing certain types of fishing activity.
[Statement 6]: Zonation systems can designate different areas with varying activity restrictions, allowing some fishing in certain zones while prohibiting fishing in others.
[Statement 7]: Studies show varied effectiveness of zonation systems for different species depending on protection levels.
[Statement 8]: Limiting or prohibiting specific fishing methods rather than all fishing can be effective.
[Statement 9]: Establishing temporary fishery closures provides time-limited restrictions rather than permanent bans.
[Statement 10]: Setting catch limits or quotas for non-targeted commercial catch can reduce unwanted catch while allowing fishing to continue.
[Statement 11]: Minimum landing size requirements can manage fishing without prohibition.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What actions are available within a marine protected area to manage fishing activity without imposing a complete ban on all fishing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several trawl net modifications appear effective for improving size-selectivity.
[Statement 2]: Rotating the orientation of diamond mesh in trawl codends by 90° improved size selection of cod, red mullet, common pandora, and round-bodied fish species.
[Statement 3]: Rotating the orientation of diamond mesh in trawl codends by 90° did not improve size selection for plaice, annular sea bream, and flatfish species.
[Statement 4]: Using different twine types with varying thickness and construction material improved size-selectivity of bottom fish, haddock, Atlantic cod, plaice, and flounder compared to thinner or other twine materials.
[Statement 5]: Size-selectivity from using different twine types was influenced by twine number and mesh orientation.
[Statement 6]: Using square mesh escape panels with square mesh codends reduced unwanted finfish catch compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 7]: The use of square mesh escape panels with square mesh codends improved size-selectivity of whiting when combined with size-sorting grids.
[Statement 8]: Fitting rigid or flexible size-sorting escape grids to trawl nets improved size-selection of haddock compared to standard nets without grids.
[Statement 9]: Fitting size-sorting escape grids to trawl nets did not improve size-selection for saithe or cod.
[Statement 10]: When combined with square mesh codends, size-sorting escape grids reduced unwanted catch of whiting, plaice, cod, and haddock compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 11]: Modifying the position and/or size of mesh escape panels improved the size-selectivity of haddock and whiting.
[Statement 12]: Increasing the mesh size of escape panels had no effect on haddock selectivity.
[Statement 13]: Modifying the position and/or size of mesh escape panels produced mixed results for cod selectivity.
[Statement 14]: Various trawl design modifications improved size-selectivity for unwanted fish species and sizes compared to standard trawl gear.
[Statement 15]: Trawl design modifications that improved size-selectivity include changes to extension piece length, codend strengthening bags, weaving methods, number of codend layers, and overall design.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Which modifications to trawl nets appear most effective for improving size-selectivity?
_claude-sonnet-4__What are the documented effects of different restrictions on line fishing, such as prohibitions or gear modifications, on fish populations and unwanted catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Different restrictions on line fishing show varying effects on fish populations and unwanted catch.
[Statement 2]: Prohibiting line fishing altogether has shown positive effects on fish populations.
[Statement 3]: One study found that prohibiting offshore line fishing and all other boat-based fishing in a marine protected area resulted in higher abundances of four fish species over-exploited by line fishing.
[Statement 4]: The over-exploited fish species were also larger in size compared to those in areas where fishing was permitted.
[Statement 5]: Prohibiting certain gear types generally reduces unwanted catch.
[Statement 6]: A study in the Kattegat found that prohibiting non-selective gear types combined with fishery closures reduced unwanted catch of cod.
[Statement 7]: A study in the Indian Ocean found higher fish density in areas where all but one gear type was prohibited compared to areas with fewer restrictions.
[Statement 8]: Longline configuration changes show mixed results for unwanted catch reduction.
[Statement 9]: Modifying longline configuration, such as increasing lead weights or using nylon instead of wire hook attachments, reduced unwanted shark and ray catches in some cases but not in others.
[Statement 10]: Survival rates of unwanted sharks and rays varied depending on the gear modification.
[Statement 11]: Nylon hook attachments showed higher survival for two of three species but lower survival for one species compared to wire attachments.
[Statement 12]: Different bait types had inconsistent effects on unwanted catch.
[Statement 13]: Six of eight studies found that using different bait types reduced unwanted catches of various species, including undersized haddock and Atlantic cod.
[Statement 14]: Two studies found no reduction in unwanted catches when using different bait types.
[Statement 15]: Global reviews found no effect of different bait types on unwanted shark and ray catches.
[Statement 16]: Gillnet modifications showed promising results for reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 17]: Three of four studies found that gillnet modifications, including reduced height, increased mesh size, and changes in twine diameter, reduced unwanted catch of cod and other discarded species.
[Statement 18]: One study found no reduction in unwanted shark catches from gillnet modifications.
[Statement 19]: Additional gear modifications like escape grids and panels in trawl nets also showed effectiveness in reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 20]: Three of four studies found reduced unwanted fish and shark catches when escape grids and panels were fitted to nets.

[Statement 1]: Several gear modifications are available for prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries to reduce unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 2]: Size-sorting escape grids, which can be rigid or flexible, can be fitted to prawn and shrimp trawl nets.
[Statement 3]: Size-sorting escape grids have been shown to reduce unwanted fish catches by allowing the escape of unwanted sharks and other fish species.
[Statement 4]: Size-sorting mesh funnels, also known as sieve nets, fitted to prawn and shrimp trawl nets have reduced catches of unwanted fish compared to standard trawls.
[Statement 5]: Large, supported escape openings such as Fisheyes, Bigeyes, and radial escape sections can be fitted to trawl nets.
[Statement 6]: Large, supported escape openings fitted to trawl nets have reduced overall catches of unwanted fish, immature red snapper, and total unwanted catch.
[Statement 7]: Combinations of size-sorting escape grids and large supported escape openings have reduced catches of unwanted fish, sharks, and rays.
[Statement 8]: Modified W-trawl net designs used in shrimp and prawn fisheries caught less non-commercial unwanted catch of crustaceans compared to traditional Florida Flyer trawl nets.
[Statement 9]: Topless, or coverless, trawls have reduced unwanted catches, including reductions in Atlantic cod and discards of commercial fish species.
[Statement 10]: Bottom trawls with parts of the gear raised off the seabed caught fewer unwanted sharks, other elasmobranchs, and fish compared to conventional trawls.
[Statement 11]: Mesh escape panels or windows with square mesh instead of diamond mesh codends have reduced the numbers of discarded finfish.
[Statement 12]: Modifications to the configuration of mesh escape panels have reduced unwanted catches.
[Statement 13]: Different designs or configurations of size-sorting escape grid systems have shown variable effectiveness in reducing unwanted catches of fish species.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries, what gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of fish?
_claude-sonnet-4__What are the most effective modifications for static fishing gear, like gillnets and traps, to reduce unwanted fish catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several modifications to static fishing gear have proven effective at reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 2]: For gillnets, modifications including reduced height, increased tension, twine diameter, and mesh size and orientation successfully reduced the unwanted catch of cod in at least one net design.
[Statement 3]: Modifications to gillnets successfully reduced discarded fish of commercial and non-commercial species.
[Statement 4]: Modifications to gillnets reduced discards of non-commercial species when compared to conventional configurations.
[Statement 5]: One study found that gillnet modifications did not typically reduce unwanted shark catches.
[Statement 6]: For fishing traps and pots, increasing mesh size reduced unwanted catches of fish overall.
[Statement 7]: Increasing mesh size in fishing traps and pots improved size-selectivity for multiple species including Atlantic cod and black sea bass.
[Statement 8]: Increasing mesh size in fishing traps and pots specifically reduced unwanted undersized mud crabs.
[Statement 9]: Fitting fishing traps and pots with escape devices, such as soft, semi-rigid, or rigid grids or frames, reduced unwanted undersized mud crabs.
[Statement 10]: Using square mesh escape windows or larger mesh sizes in traps and pots improved the size-selectivity of Atlantic cod, black sea bass and most fish species.
[Statement 11]: Using different trap types with various escape devices reduced unwanted catches of multiple fish species including brown trout, black sea bass, herring, bluethroat wrasse, leatherjacket, cod, protected rockfishes, whitefish, American eel, winter flounder, and sharks/rays.
[Statement 12]: The combination of fitting escape frames with larger mesh sizes appeared particularly effective at reducing unwanted undersized catches.
[Statement 13]: Using different bait species in traps did not change the amount of unwanted invertebrates caught.

[Statement 1]: Commercial prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries can use several gear modifications to reduce unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 2]: Size-sorting escape grids fitted to prawn and shrimp trawl nets are one of the most widely studied gear modifications.
[Statement 3]: Size-sorting escape grids reduce unwanted fish catches by allowing the escape of non-commercial species and discarded commercial species or sizes.
[Statement 4]: Different designs and configurations of escape grids have been tested, with some studies finding reduced unwanted catches of fish species.
[Statement 5]: Size-sorting mesh funnels, also known as sieve nets, fitted to prawn and shrimp trawl nets reduce catches of unwanted non-commercial or discarded fish compared to standard trawls.
[Statement 6]: Combining escape grids with large, supported escape openings reduces catches of unwanted fish, sharks, and rays.
[Statement 7]: The configuration of mesh escape panels or windows, including their position, size, and mesh size, can be modified.
[Statement 8]: Modifying mesh escape panels or windows has been shown to reduce unwanted catches of certain fish species like whiting, haddock, and boarfish.
[Statement 9]: When mesh escape panels or windows are combined with size-sorting grids, the unwanted catch of fish, sharks, and stingrays can be reduced compared to standard unmodified trawl nets.
[Statement 10]: Raising parts of bottom trawl gear off the seabed reduces catches of unwanted sharks, other elasmobranchs, and fish species.
[Statement 11]: Topless or coverless trawls can reduce unwanted catches, particularly for Atlantic cod and discards of commercial fish species.
[Statement 12]: Moving stimulator devices fitted to trawl nets can increase the escape response of fish.
[Statement 13]: The effectiveness of moving stimulator devices varies by species and sometimes requires combination with other devices.
[Statement 14]: Modified designs of W-trawl nets for shrimp and prawn fisheries catch less non-commercial unwanted crustaceans compared to traditional Florida Flyer trawl nets.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of fish in commercial prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Multiple controlled studies provide evidence that various gear modifications can improve the size-selectivity of commercial fishing gear.
[Statement 2]: Modifications to trawl gear improved the size-selectivity for unwanted fish species or sizes.
[Statement 3]: Trawl gear modifications included changes to the length of the extension piece, the codend strengthening bag, the method of weaving, the number of codend layers and overall design.
[Statement 4]: In one of two cases, modifications to trawl gear improved size-selectivity for annular seabream.
[Statement 5]: Using different twine types, based on thickness and construction material, improved the size-selectivity for bottom fish, haddock, Atlantic cod, plaice and flounder.
[Statement 6]: Different types or configurations of size-sorting escape grid systems in trawl nets resulted in better size-selectivity for unwanted redfish and Greenland halibut.
[Statement 7]: Different types or configurations of size-sorting escape grid systems in trawl nets resulted in better size-selectivity for commercial target hake.
[Statement 8]: Turning the orientation of diamond mesh in trawl codends by 90° resulted in better size selection of cod, red mullet, common pandora, and round-bodied fish species.
[Statement 9]: Turning the orientation of diamond mesh in trawl codends by 90° did not result in better size selection for plaice, annular sea bream, and flatfish species.
[Statement 10]: Some gear modifications showed limited effects on size-selectivity.
[Statement 11]: A replicated study in the North Sea found that reducing the size of the main body of a trawl net did not improve the size-selection of cod and haddock.
[Statement 12]: The effect of using a different design or configuration of a size-sorting escape grid system on improving the size-selectivity of trawls varied between fish species.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence for gear modifications improving the size-selectivity of commercial fishing gear?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several ecological outcomes have been observed from different approaches to managing small-scale traditional fisheries.
[Statement 2]: In the Adriatic Sea, a marine protected area zone allowing only artisanal fishing activity for three years had higher overall commercial catch rates of five of seven fish species compared to unprotected areas openly fished.
[Statement 3]: In the Bismark Sea, an area closed to customary fishing for eight years showed higher abundance of only one of seven fish species compared to an area open to customary fishing.
[Statement 4]: In an area of the Bismark Sea closed to customary fishing, six of seven fish species had a lower flight response distance.
[Statement 5]: The lower flight response distance made the fish species more vulnerable to capture with spear guns.
[Statement 6]: In the Foveaux Straight, a customary fisheries area with community-based management had more New Zealand scallops compared to both a protected area prohibiting all fishing and an area allowing recreational harvest.
[Statement 7]: The scallops in the Foveaux Straight's customary fisheries area tended to be smaller.
[Statement 8]: Results from prohibiting commercial fishing while allowing other activities varied depending on the specific management approach.
[Statement 9]: Marine protected areas prohibiting commercial fishing showed mixed results for lobster populations.
[Statement 10]: Some studies of marine protected areas prohibiting commercial fishing found no increase in lobster abundance over 12 years.
[Statement 11]: Other studies found bigger lobsters in marine protected areas compared to fished areas.
[Statement 12]: A global review found that 10 of 11 studies showed higher fish abundance inside areas with fishing restrictions compared to areas without restrictions.
[Statement 13]: A global review found that five out of 11 studies showed larger fish inside protected areas.
[Statement 14]: When territorial user rights for fisheries were established, one study found larger-sized and more numerous egg capsules of Chilean abalone compared to open-access areas.
[Statement 15]: When territorial user rights for fisheries were established, one study found more larvae of Chilean abalone compared to open-access areas.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the documented ecological outcomes of managing small-scale traditional fisheries, either through prohibition or by making them the only permitted fishing type?
